speaker: Doctor
text: How long have you been experiencing pain in your left shoulder?

speaker: Patient
text: About 2 months now, doctor. It started slowly and has been getting worse over time.

speaker: Doctor
text: The pain started about 6 months ago, but it's been getting worse over the past 3 months. Can you tell me if the pain is constant or does it come and go?

speaker: Patient
text: It's pretty constant, doctor, but it does get a bit worse when I move my arm in certain ways. Like when I try to reach up high or lift something heavy.

speaker: Doctor
text: The pain is pretty constant, but it does seem to get a bit worse when I lift my arm above my head or when I'm carrying something heavy.

speaker: Patient
text: It's really been bothering me at night, doctor. I have trouble sleeping on my left side because of the pain.

speaker: Doctor
text: Do you have any numbness or tingling sensations in your arm or hand, especially when you're experiencing the pain?

speaker: Patient
text: No, doctor, I don't have any numbness or tingling sensations in my arm or hand. But I do have trouble doing things that require a lot of movement, like brushing my hair.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any weight loss or fever recently?

speaker: Patient
text: Actually, doctor, I have been experiencing some difficulty sleeping, but not just because of the pain. I've been having trouble falling asleep and staying asleep because of the discomfort.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any changes in your daily activities due to this pain, such as difficulty sleeping or performing daily tasks?

speaker: Patient
text: Yes, doctor, it's definitely affected my daily activities. I have trouble dressing myself, and simple things like brushing my hair have become a challenge.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you had any previous injuries or conditions that could have caused chronic pain in your shoulder?

speaker: Patient
text: No, doctor, I've never had any injuries or conditions that I'm aware of that could have caused this kind of pain. I do have type 2 diabetes, but I've been managing it with my medication.

speaker: Doctor
text: Do you have any family history of joint problems or autoimmune diseases, such as rheumatoid arthritis?

speaker: Patient
text: No, doctor, I don't have any family history of joint problems or autoimmune diseases.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any stiffness or limited range of motion in your left shoulder?

speaker: Patient
text: Yes, doctor, I do feel a bit stiff when I try to move my arm in certain ways. It's especially noticeable when I try to lift it above my head or reach behind my back.

speaker: Doctor
text: I've made a note of that. Can you tell me if the pain in your left shoulder is radiating or traveling down your arm at all?

speaker: Patient
text: No, doctor, it's just localized to my shoulder, but it does feel like it's getting worse when I move my arm in certain ways, like I mentioned before.

speaker: Doctor
text: Now that I've taken note of the stiffness, I'd like to examine your left shoulder more closely. Can you please lift your arm above your head for me, so I can see how much range of motion you have?

speaker: Patient
text: That's a bit uncomfortable, doctor. It hurts when I lift it all the way up.

speaker: Doctor
text: I've observed some stiffness in your shoulder joint, and it seems like you're having trouble lifting your arm above your head. Can you tell me if you've experienced any clicking or snapping sensations in your shoulder when you move it?

speaker: Patient
text: Yes, doctor, I do get a bit of a clicking sensation when I try to lift my arm or move it in certain ways. It's been happening more often lately, and it's been really bothering me.

speaker: Doctor
text: I've taken note of your limited range of motion and stiffness in the shoulder joint. Have you tried any over-the-counter pain medications or physical therapy to alleviate the pain?

speaker: Patient
text: I've tried taking ibuprofen a few times, doctor, but it only seems to provide temporary relief. And as for physical therapy, I haven't had the chance to go yet, but I've been doing some exercises on my own to try and loosen up my shoulder.

speaker: Doctor
text: I've noted your responses so far, and I'm starting to piece together a possible diagnosis. Have you ever had any previous surgeries or procedures on your shoulder or arm?

speaker: Patient
text: Actually, doctor, I've had a few minor procedures in the past, but nothing major. I had a biopsy a few years ago for a lump on my neck, but it turned out to be benign.

speaker: Doctor
text: You mentioned you've been experiencing pain for about 6 months now, and it's been getting worse. Have you noticed any weakness or fatigue in your left arm, especially when you're lifting heavy objects or performing daily tasks?

speaker: Patient
text: To be honest, doctor, I do feel a bit fatigued when I'm doing activities that require a lot of movement, but I wouldn't say it's weakness exactly. More like my arm just feels like it's giving out on me after a while.

speaker: Doctor
text: I've made a note of your history of chronic pain in the left shoulder. Can you tell me if you've experienced any muscle spasms or cramping in your shoulder or arm area when the pain is acting up?

speaker: Patient
text: Actually, doctor, I have experienced some muscle spasms in my shoulder when I'm trying to move it or lift heavy objects. It's quite uncomfortable, and it feels like my muscles are tensing up.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any redness, swelling, or warmth in your left shoulder or arm, which could indicate inflammation or infection?

speaker: Patient
text: No, doctor, I don't have any redness, swelling, or warmth in my left shoulder or arm. It just feels stiff and sore when I move it.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you ever had any previous tests or imaging done on your left shoulder, such as X-rays or an MRI?

speaker: Patient
text: Yes, doctor, I did have an X-ray done a few months ago, but the results didn't show anything out of the ordinary. The doctor at the time said I had some minor degenerative changes in my shoulder joint, but that it wasn't anything to worry about.

speaker: Doctor
text: I've made a note of your previous surgeries and procedures on your shoulder or arm. Have you experienced any pain or numbness in your left shoulder after any of those procedures?

speaker: Patient
text: No, doctor, I didn't experience any pain or numbness in my shoulder after any of those procedures. The biopsy on my neck was actually the only significant medical issue I've had, and that was a few years ago.

speaker: Doctor
text: Based on your history of chronic left shoulder pain, limited range of motion, and stiffness, I'm concerned that we might be looking at a condition such as frozen shoulder or adhesive capsulitis.
